base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Mature romantic', 'Full label': '"Having a mature romantic relationship"'}
explanation: A mature romantic relationship centers on relationship maintenance: balancing empathic understanding with clear self-advocacy. Agent 1 aims to validate and accurately read the partner’s internal states (curbing dispositional blame), while Agent 2 aims to assert needs without accusation (shifting talk toward situational framing and collaboration). These intentions are observable in conversational tone, framing, and responses, aligning with attribution theory.
first_agent_goal: Demonstrate active understanding by paraphrasing the partner’s concerns and explicitly naming the feelings they express while maintaining a calm, non-defensive tone.
second_agent_goal: Assert personal needs and boundaries using direct, non-accusatory language that invites joint problem-solving rather than attributing fault.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] sit down for a scheduled relationship check-in the night before they must decide whether to sign a joint lease. Tension is high after [Agent 2] saw a photo timestamp showing [Agent 1] having one-on-one drinks with a coworker right after saying they were stuck late at work. [Agent 2] has been feeling chronically dismissed when plans change last-minute and when phones are used during their limited time together; they intend to set boundaries around advance notice for schedule changes, clarity about one-on-one socializing, and no phones during meals. [Agent 1], stressed by a new project and worried about being cast as dishonest or uncaring, has committed to a non-defensive stance: paraphrasing [Agent 2]’s concerns and explicitly naming the emotions behind them. Both want a mature, stable partnership but hold competing interpretations of the same behaviors—disrespect and secrecy versus workload norms and spontaneity—and must agree on concrete expectations under time pressure. Previous conversations have devolved into [Agent 2] escalating when feeling unsafe and [Agent 1] minimizing with situational explanations, so both are trying to break this pattern while deciding on rules that feel fair to both.', 'explanation': 'The scene creates attributional ambiguity around the same behavior (staying out and phone use): [Agent 2] tends toward dispositional attributions (you don’t care/you hide things), while [Agent 1] favors situational attributions (work demands/social pressure). High stakes (imminent lease), perceived trust violations, and prior demand–withdraw cycles make the interaction hard. The goals are complementary but challenging: [Agent 1] must validate without defending, countering the self-serving bias; [Agent 2] must assert needs with non-accusatory language, reducing characterological blame and inviting joint problem-solving. Success requires reframing attributions and negotiating boundaries under emotional load, directly engaging relationship maintenance dynamics.'}
